S TAT ION W B A A
LAFAYETTE. INDIANA
July 30, 1968
Mr. Ken Clark
Project Director
Radio Programs for the Disadvantaged
National Educational Radio
1346 Connecticut Avenue N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20036
Dear Mr. Clark:
"We are very interested in the 19 6 8 Urban Broadcasting Work¬
shop to be held at American University. We would like to
have more information on the Workshop through this newslet-
ter in the hope that we can plan and sponsor such a work- /
shop next summer at -Purdue/ _. _/
WBAA's contribution to programming for the disadvantaged is
in the planning stage at present. We are working on the
programming ideas with the Purdue University advisor to
black students and the chairman of the local Human Relations
Council. These people have told us they are.exhausted by
discussion of- the problems of being a Negro in Lafayette
or elsewhere. They have "asked that we present programs
that will give solutions to the problems. However, we can¬
not, in whatever programming we present, limit our defini¬
tion of "disadvantaged” to mean "Negro." Lafayette has a
small Negro community but a much larger group of very poor
people* For this reason we are interested in program ideas
with a broader base.
Specific problems that seek solutions include home owner¬
ship, buying on credit and the training of what are presently
the unemployable. We are also interested in putting city
officials on the air with the opportunity for anyone to.
call in questions, problems and comments. We are planning
future meetings with members of the Human Relations Council
to begin work on some of these programsiaeas, and hope¬
fully, many others.
Sincerely,
Jane Root
